text: ..-is in an uproar. The PRIME MINISTER, NEVILLE CHAMBERLA (71), sits with the MAJORITY, RULING CONSERVATIVE PARTY o one side of the house... .--whilst the LEADER of the MINORITY, OPPOSITION LABOUR PARTY, CLEMENT ATTLEE (57) sits with the OPPOSITION PARTI on the other side. They face each other like two warring armies. Shouting. Accusations. Wild gesturing. Paper darts thrown. Mayhem.
ATTLEE rises to his feet, amid jeers and heckles, to deno CHAMBERLAIN, directly opposite him across the aisle -
Mr Speaker! Mr Speaker!
The Honourable Leader of the Opposition, Clement Attlee!

Mr Speaker--Mr Speaker--it seems I have not been clear enough. Then let me leave no doubt regarding my feelings about Mr Chamberlain's future as Prime Minister. (over boos and applause) Owing to his years of inactivity and incompetence - (cheers and boos) (MORE )

- we find him personally responsible, personally responsible for leaving our nation ruinously unprepared to face the present Nazi peril. We are at war, Mr Speaker. At war. And leaving aside whether he is fit to be a leader in peace- time he has proven himself incapable of leading us in war- time. Cries of support to this - Looking down from the LORDS GALLERY is - VISCOUNT HALIFAX (59), appalled by what he is seeing. He exchanges a look the bereft CHAMBERLAIN.

Therefore, in the national interest, we the Opposition, are willing to enter into a Grand Coalition--with the “ruling” Conservative Party, so-called!... An OPPOSITION MP stands and starts singing "Rule Britanni Others soon begin to join in.
Order! Order!

..-but not, and I stress this, never, under the leadership of Mr Chamberlain... (angle on CHAMBERLAIN) -.-who has lost the confidence of this House! A REBEL CONSERVATIVE MEMBER rises and crosses the floor t stand with the OPPOSITION MPs, betraying Chamberlain.
(directly to CHAMBERLAIN) In the country’s interest man, resign! Step down! And let us find a new leader! UPROAR, and many cry “HEAR-HEAR!” and “GO!”
I said, ORDER! The camera passes along the CONSERVATIVE benches to find ANTHONY EDEN (43), behind him sits KINGSLEY WOOD (59).
(into EDEN's ear) Where’s Winston? On the bench beside EDEN, as if to reserve a space, is a Royal Naval Yacht Club CAP.

Ensuring his fingerprints are not on the murder weapon. The singing of “Rule Britannia" continues over - INT. DINING ROOM/ SIR JOHN SIMON’S COUNTRY HOUSE - NIGHT NEVILLE CHAMBERLAIN addresses the other CONSERVATIVE gues gathered around a circular dining table.

Accordingly--tomorrow--I will resign as Prime Minister. GREAT FEAR in the faces of the NOBLES. CUT BETWEEN their FACES, during the following - CHAMBERLAIN (CONT’D) (suppressing emotion) As the Opposition refuse to join a government headed by me, we must select my successor. (beat) I will step down tomorrow but I wanted my own party, the gentlemen I most respect, to know first. LORD LONDONDERRY. Halifax. There’s no question! Our Foreign Secretary -
No contest! HALIFAX

I appreciate your confidence but my time has yet to come. However, on whomever the task may fall, he shall be charged with the security of these islands and of our Empire, and shall be required to explore all avenues.
Including that of Diplomatic talks.
Indeed, towards the restoration of peace in Europe.
Hear Hear!!!
Gentlemen, I’m afraid there is only one candidate. Only, one man that the Opposition will accept?
Oh no.
Surely not...

A plate of BACON & EGGS is set on a BREAKFAST TRAY. Then. glass of WHITE WINE is poured by WINSTON’s VALET, SAWYERS and set beside the plate. A glass of SCOTCH and SODA is a prepared and set beside these on the tray. For Breakfast? SAWYERS carries the TRAY through servants quarters toward the ENTRANCE HALL of the house, where -— - the TRAY passes by - WINSTON’s PRIVATE SECRETARY, JOHN EVANS (35), as he schools the NEW YOUNG SECRETARY, ELIZAB LAYTON. Evans, an immaculately-groomed rake, snobbishly thinks himself infinitely superior to the Elizabeth Layto of the world.

(to ELIZABETH) -..and if he stretches out his hand and says, “Gimme”, you need to anticipate what he wants - black pen, red pen, paper, or “Clop”, that’s his hole punch. EVANS and LAYTON walk past - - SAWYERS-with-TRAY, as he waits for the COOK to iron a NEWSPAPER (DAILY EXPRESS)and as the SCULLERY MAIDS, over shoulder, ANXIOUSLY read the headline: “CHAMBERLAIN TO RESIGN”
Don’t smudge the ink.
How selfish to resign, time like this.
D’you think they’11l take me to Downing Street?
Not after the Spotted Dick you served last week. The COOK then sets the PAPER on the TRAY, whereupon SAWYE carries the TRAY up the stairs.
EVANS and LAYTON approach a BEDROOM DOORWAY.

...-He mumbles, so it’s almost impossible to catch everything. And be prepared to type fast - short bursts - and double-spaced, he hates single-spaced--hates it! Good luck. EVANS knocks on the door, opens it and then pushes the no quaking ELIZABETH LAYTON inside, closing the door again.

Her POV of the dimly-lit room. And then, a MATCH is struc CIGAR lit. We can just make out a MAN in bed, as -— SAWYERS tugs open the CURTAINS, revealing - - WINSTON CHURCHILL (65), in BED, with the BREAKFAST TRAY his lap, in a pink silk dressing-gown (naked beneath). Hi dispatch box, piled high with telegrams, stands open by h bed . His marmalade cat, TANGO, sits at the end of the be as WINSTON reads a dispatch and dictates...

To the French Ambassador. Come on -— WINSTON looks up at ELIZABETH, to see if she is writing t down. She’s not - WINSTON (CONT’D) - telegram! ELIZABETH realises, to her horror, that the dictation has already begun, and she hurries to the TYPE-WRITER, which already been loaded with a sheet...She begins to type FAS in short bursts - WINSTON (CONT’D) (dictating) With German forces crossing into Holland...Holland alone...request reassurance...that French forces will now move--move at once--to protect Belgium. Stop. Read!
(nervously) “To--to the French Ambassador. With German forces crossing into Holland...Holland alone... request reassurance that -
- immediate reassurance - ELIZABETH adjusts the typewriter’s carriage and paten and types the word “IMMEDIATE” above the previous text...
“— immediate - reassurance - “
“ — that -" Go on - “- that ” SAWYERS enters, as ELIZABETH struggles to re-set the carriage.
“— that - “ The BEDROOM TELEPHONE rings -—-
French Ambassador sir -

Monsieur Ambassador! (pause) Ah. They’ve already invaded Belgium. (pause) I will convey your plea to the Prime Minister at once. Yes, the situation is still very confused. Goodbye. WINSTON hangs up. A concerned pause, and then - WINSTON (CONT’D) Holland and Belgium. ELIZABETH types this - tap,tap,tap,tap - WINSTON (CONT’D) No, no, no.
(confused) Sir?

Scrap that. New telegram.  7. In a fluster, she pulls out the old PAGE from the TYPEWRI CARRIAGE and quickly inserts a new page, as - WINSTON (CONT’D) To General Ismay... WINSTON grabs his WHISKEY and SODA, as - the PHONE rings again. SAWYERS re-appears.
Dammit Sawyers! What is it now?!
Your son. WINSTON, his concentration broken, goes to the PHONE.

(into Phone) Randolph, quickly - (listens) Last night they said I may be made Prime Minister today. But that was yesterday. Let’s see what Neville does today. Thank--thank you my boy. Keep buggering on! Puts down the phone. Turns to look at ELIZABETH. WINSTON (CONT’D) Now... Sips his SCOTCH. This calms him.
General Ismay... Moving to the end of the bed -

Ah, General Ismay. (to Sawyers) Sawyers - get rid of this will you? Winston gestures to Sawyers to move his tray away and the swings his legs - indecorously! - out of bed. ELIZABETH quickly turns her face away! WINSTON then begins to pace WINSTON (CONT’D) In the light of today’s events, the time is ripe for many preparations to be made... (beat) Are you striking those typewriter keys in a normal fashion? It’s awfully loud, I can’t think! (beat) Read it back.
Ahh--To General Ismay. In the light of today’s events, the time is right for many prep -
RIPE! Not RIGHT! God's teeth girl! I said ripe, ripe, ripe - P-P-P! The last sentence...
(shaken) The--the time is ripe...
For! FOR!
(her nerve broken) ..-Many...Many...many...

How many “many”s did you write?! One many! (sighs) “For...for MANY preparations-—- to be made...” He walks up to her and looks over her chair, and is horri to see - WINSTON (CONT’D) Single-spaced? What are you doing?! What are you doing?!
Someone set it on single-spaced and before I realised -
Then why did you persist?!
As she starts to rush out -
Tell Evans to send me someone who can do it right the first time!

ELIZABETH comes down the stairs, and stops, her face tear stained.  CLEMENTINE CHURCHILL - WINSTON’s WIFE, 55 YEARS OLD - beautiful, elegant, highly-strung, is at that moment cros the hall, with a HANDFUL of BROWN ENVELOPES. She sees ELIZABETH.
Ah. He shouted at you. Did he shout at you?
Yes, but I....
He can be an awful brute.
No! I made too many mistakes.
I think you were nervous. And he has a knack for drawing out the very worst in those trying to help him the most.
Oh it’s not him. It’s me. He’s - he’s -
He’s just a man, like any other. Wait here. CLEMMIE climbs the stairs.
CLEMMIE enters - WINSTON (on his knees) is looking for Ta the cat under his bed.
My Darling?
The War Cabinet has been called. The bloody cat is under the bed again. CLEMMIE indicates that SAWYERS should go and moves around WINSTON tucking his shirt in.
Can I tell you something that I feel you ought to know? He looks at her -  10.
I’ve noticed a recent deterioration in your manner. You're not so kind as you used to be. You’ve become rough, sarcastic, over-bearing and rude.
Is this about the new girl?
If the King asks you to become Prime Minister -
We don’t know that -
I don’t want you to be disliked.
More than I already am?

Darling, you may be on the brink, the brink--of having tremendous power, surpassed only by the King. With such power you really must try to be more kind and, if possible, calm. I want others to love and respect you as I do. Clemmie falls back in the bed, shortly joined by Winston- they share a moment of fondness.

WIDE SHOT of Chartwell bathed in sunshine. ELIZABETH LAYT with hat and coat now on, is attempting to make a discree escape from the house but is stopped by a MOTORCYCLE COUR with a telegram to deliver. We do not hear what is said. CLOSE-UP on the telegram turning in ELIZABETH’S hands as COURIER rides away. ELIZABETH looks back to the house, ma her decision and re-enters the lair.
ELIZABETH climbs the stairs holding a telegram, braced to once more enter the Lion’s Den. She enters -
- and finds WINSTON, CLEMMIE, JOHN EVANS, SAWYERS and a M all listening with rapt attention to a RADIO BROADCAST.
“This is BBC Home Service. Here is a short news bulletin. The German army invaded Holland and Belgium early this morning, by land, and land parachutes--
There’s a telegram.
Sssshhh!
..."The Armies of the Low Countries are resisting. An appeal for help has been made to the Allied governments and Brussels says the Allied troops are moving to their Support...”
It's from the Palace. All eyes turn to look at her, as if an elephant has enter the room. A silent beat in which no-one breathes.
Thank you, Miss...?
Layton.
CLEMMIE hands WINSTON his watch, glasses, cigar case, mat and a sugar cube.
You’re shaking.
So are you! It’s true CLEMMIE is just as nervous -
You from excitement--I from terror. You have been wanting this your entire adult life.
No--since the nursery. CLEMMIE laughs.  12. WINSTON (CONT’D) But do the public want me?
It’s your own Party to whom you’1l have to prove yourself.
I’m getting the job only because the ship is sinking. It’s not a gift, it’s revenge.
Let them see your true qualities. Your courage...
---My poor judgement.
.-.-Your lack of vanity.
...-My iron will.
(in playful rebuke) ...Your sense of humour.
Ho Ho Ho!
Now go.
Go?
Be.
Be? She touches his face tenderly -
Yourself.

Which self? CLEMMIE walks away. WINSTON turns to a wall on which are hung many HATS - (Royal Naval Yacht Club Cap, Admiral’s h with plume, aviator helmet with goggles, riding hat, pith helmet, French WWl helmet, fez, Homburg, top hat, etc ) a on display like HUNTING TROPHIES.  13. WINSTON (CONT’D) (to himself) Which self should I be today? WINSTON surveys the collection, then plucks the TOP HAT f its hook - WINSTON (CONT’D) One should have had power when a young man. When wits were sharp, sinews strong. Oh well. He returns to her - WINSTON (CONT’D) Lead on Macduff-- When youth departs-- may wisdom prove enough. They kiss, and she gives him a silver BOX OF MATCHES, embossed with loving message from his children. EXT/INT. PRINCES STREET/ WINSTON’S CAR - DAY WINSTON, in the back seat, (with JOHN EVANS in front) loo out the window at the human traffic - seems like he’s ina gold-fish bowl, disconnected. He watches as - MEN IN BOWL HATS and YOUNG WOMEN in SUMMER DRESSES walk to work.
Hardly seems like there’s a war on at all. THREE DELIVERY BOYS ride by on bicycles, notice him and w excitedly.
How odd it is.
Sir? They stop, waiting behind a BUS.
You know--I have never ridden a bus. Never queued for bread. I believe I can boil an egg but only because I saw it done once.
WINSTON’s car approaches the Palace gates, which are open The CAR drives up to the PALACE. WINSTON gets out and he EVANS enter the PALACE -—  14.
A grand hall. Winston removing his hat and coat, hands his cane and glo then hat to a LIVERIED DOORMAN whilst a LIVERIED STAFF ME waits nearby.

The only time I tried to ride the Underground was during the General Strike. Clemmie dropped me at South Kensington station. I went down-- but I got lost and came straight back up. Awful! (girding himself) Well, “Here we go”...
Good luck sir. WINSTON strides away, following the EQUERRY.
KING GEORGE VI (agitated, troubled) speaks with the ill, weak, outgoing PRIME-MINISTER NEVILLE CHAMBERLAIN. CHAMBERLAIN watches the KING.
Why not Halifax? I favour Halifax.
I wanted Halifax. The Lords wanted Halifax. Halifax wanted Halifax.
Then--then why have I been forced to send for Churchill?
Because he’s the only member of our party who has the support of the Opposition.

His record is a litany of catastrophe. Gallipoli, 25,000 dead. The India Policy. Russian Civil War. The Gold Standard. The the the Abdication. And now this Norway ‘adventure’. What, eighteen hundred men?  15.
One aircraft carrier, two cruisers, seven destroyers and a submarine.
Winston lacks judgement.
He was right about Hitler.
Even a stopped clock is right twice a day. EQUERRY enters.
First Lord of the Admiralty, Mr Winston Churchill!
Early.
Keen.
I accept your resignation--but I want you to know--how--cruelly I think you’ve been treated.
Thank you Your Majesty. He and GEORGE shake hands.
This way, my Lord. The KING waits - SIGHS deeply, until... We hear footsteps approaching. WINSTON enters.
Your Majesty.
Mr Churchill.
I believe you know why I--I I have asked you here today.
Sir, I simply can’t imagine why.  16.
It is my duty to-to-to invite you to take up - the position of of Prime Minister of this United Kingdom. Will you form a government?
I will.
Very well. WINSTON bows, and when the KING offers his hand, WINSTON kisses it. WINSTON rises.
That was--quite easy.
Yes. They stare at each other in uneasy silence. WINSTON (CONT’D) I believe we are to meet regularly.
Once a week, I’m afraid. How are you on--on--on Mondays?
I shall endeavour to be available on Mondays.
Four o'clock?
(resolutely) I nap at 4.
Is that--permissible?
No. But necessary. I work late.
Then perhaps lunch?
Lunch! Mondays. (WINSTON bows) Your majesty.
Prime Minister.  17. When WINSTON backs out of the room, the KING anxiously li a cigarette, and broods.

WINSTON pulls up in his PRIVATE CAR, alights, (followed b EVANS) waves at the PRESS, an effortless SELF-PUBLICIST, total ease in the spotlight. Ever the showman - taps the NUMBER 10 on the famous front door with his walking stick the amusement of the PHOTOGRAPHERS -—
Prime Minister? First order of business, sir?
A glass of Pol Roger! He enters the building, and -
- is greeted by EDEN.
Prime Minister!
Anthony.
How was the K-k-king?
Anxious. Never forgiven me for supporting his brother’s marriage to Wallis Simpson. WINSTON and EDEN step into his office, with WINSTON closi the door on EVANS in the hallway.
You only have to meet him once a week.
That's like saying you only have to have your tooth pulled once a week. EDEN takes out a pen, opens a notebook -  18.
Composition of your War Cabinet. Who should sit on it?
Chamberlain. And the Reverend “Holy Fox" —-
(writes) Halifax. Keeping your enemies close?
More than that, without them the party will get rid of me. (beat) And that sheep in sheep’s clothing, Attlee. MARY, CHURCHILL’s 18 year old daughter, appears in the doorway.
Come on Daddy--everyone’s waiting.
Be there in a jiffy, my love. MARY exits.
I heard that before you were asked, they offered it to Lord Halifax.
(shakes head) I doubt that. Halifax would never turn it down. He's the fourth son of an Earl. Fourth sons turn nothing down.
I only wish the position had come your way in better times, sir. You have an enormous task ahead of you.
I hope it’s not too late. I am very much afraid it is. But we can only do our best.
CLEMMIE and the CHURCHILL CHILDREN wear GAS-MASKS as they shout -  19.
Hip Hip -
WINSTON enters - and stops, aghast, and stares at his fam
Good lord, what a frightful sight!

CHURCHILL (29) and his WIFE PAMELA (pregnant), and MARY CHURCHILL (18) all pull off their GAS MASKS, grab their glasses of CHAMPAGNE, then converge on him and kiss him. He stares at them, a SMILE FORMING AT LAST, deeply touche actually. He is presented with a glass of champagne.
Thank you. Thank you. PAMELA raises her glass -
A toast! Come on!
Yes! Mary makes her way to sit on a cushion on the floor next Winston. She looks proudly at WINSTON -

My darling husband--Something you all might not know is that on the eve of our marriage I got “cold feet”--but as I’d already called off two engagements by the age of 21 I was in danger of gaining a reputation for being a ‘bolter’-- and it would’ve been poor form to call off a third! LAUGHTER. WINSTON smiles.
Hear hear.
Lucky for Daddy.  20.

But the real reason for my wintry feet was because I knew, even then, that his priority would be public life. It worried a young girl greatly--this wretched thought of coming second, eternally. But so it has proven to be. And in due course (Mary takes Winstons hand) our children would also have to make their own peace with this same fact. (directly to Winston) We all did, you see, in our own ways. And now, today, we all receive our reward--proof that our small sacrifice was for a far, far greater good. I give you, your father, my beloved husband - the Prime Minister.
Prime Minister! They raise their GLASSES in a toast -—
Here's to--(thinks) not buggering it up.
Not buggering it up!
BIG BEN starts the WESTMINSTER CHIME -
WINSTON approaches EDEN in the ancient hall and together climb the steps beneath the great gothic WINDOW.
Belgium was a ploy. They just punched through the Ardennes into France and crossed the Meuse in under 24 hours!
No-one can cross the Meuse River in 24 hours.
Apparently the Germans can.  21.
BIG BEN strikes the hour - 3 PM.

To the sound of the distant BELLS, WINSTON enters, with EDEN, and small knuckle-knocking on woodwork, mainly from LABOUR benches. WINSTON looks around, not actually surprised at the contemptuous reception.

(to EDEN) Contempt. Well, you have to start somewhere. In the LORDS GALLERY, above, HALIFAX enters and looks dow proceedings, and on - WINSTON, looking at his FOB-WATCH. The HUBBUB dies down and WINSTON puts on his GLASSES.
(whispered, to SIMON) Here we go. WINSTON reaches into his waistcoat for his TYPED SPEECH, delivers his MAIDEN SPEECH as PRIME MINISTER...

Mr Speaker. On Friday evening last-- I received His Majesty’s commission to form a new administration... ANGLE ON: CONSERVATIVE MP’s, all looking worried. WINSTON (CONT’D) -..It was the evident wish and will of Parliament, and the Nation, that this should be conceived on the broadest possible basis, and that it should include all parties.
CLOSE ON: TYPED PAGE (with TEXT) being rapidly tugged fro TYPEWRITER CARRIAGE (to a LOUD explosive ratchet-whirr)!!

A War Cabinet has been convened...  22. CLOSE ON: TYPE-WRITER keys typing...”A War Cabinet has be convened” — WIDE: ELIZABETH TYPES, as WINSTON dictates - WINSTON (CONT’D) Correction - “has been formed” - ELIZABETH adjusts the PATEN, then types - “formed” above “convened” —
- has been formed--of five members -
...representing, with the Opposition parties, the unity of the Nation.

CLOSE ON: A FRESHLY TYPED PAGE (ROUGH DRAFT) is set down the desk by ELIZABETH’s hand. The stationary bears the Pr Minister's monogram, and we see typed TEXT plus several phrases struck out (between parentheses). The CAMERA moves in on the paragraph that reads... “The three party Leaders have agreed to serve, either in the War Cabinet, or in (positions of authority*) high executive office.” (* denotes struck through phrase)
The three party Leaders have agreed to serve, either in the War Cabinet-
- or in high executive - or in high executive office. office. WINSTON (CONT’D) The three fighting Services have been filled.
OUTSIDE the BATHROOM DOOR - ELIZABETH LAYTON waits, with PAD and PAPER, taking down his dictation...  23.
Sawyers is she there?
Yes she is.. I mean, I am
Don’t come in! SOUNDS of him taking a BATH, the SPONGE being squeezed ov his head...She starts to move away, but is arrested by -
Don’t go away!
No, no--I’m still here.

“With this agreement, I now invite the House - (water sounds) - by the resolution which stands in my name, to record its approval, and to declare its confidence in the new government.” Sound of WINSTON getting out of the BATH.
Miss? I’m coming out in a state of nature! ELIZABETH LAYTON flees, as the DOOR opens and as WINSTON (naked) looks up and down the HALLWAY to see where his TY has gone.
I now invite the House by a resolution to declare its confidence in the new government. ANGLE on the CONSERVATIVE PARTY - unimpressed. KINGSLEY-WOOD advises A JUNIOR CONSERVATIVE, ERNLE HASTIN

Look to Chamberlain’s handkerchief. If he waves it at the end of Churchill's speech, we show approval, if not, keep quiet. ERNLE HASTINGS looks over at CHAMBERLAIN.  24. CHAMBERLAIN, still on the front bench but not in the PM’s chair, draws a WHITE HANDKERCHIEF out of his BREAST POCKE and folds it in his LAP. ERNLE HASTINGS nods - understanding.
It must be remembered that we are in the preliminary stage of one of the greatest battles in history...

CLOSE ON: A HEAVILY MARKED-UP PAGE of TYPED SPEECH (ROUGH DRAFT) much worked-over, annotated, altered - with WINSTO HAND just then adding the latest change in the margins... see his HAND write (in his tiny cursive scrawl) - and that many (arrangements*) preparations have to be made here at home.
...and that many preparations have to be made here at home. WIDE: WINSTON, alone in his OFFICE, hunkered at NIGHT, go through the speech, meticulous, obsessive, a perfectionis
Sir, I take up my task with buoyancy and hope -

CLOSE ON: The TYPEWRITER hammers typing the CLEAN (FINAL) DRAFT of the speech, on SMALLER SHEETS of PAPER, the TEXT set out like BLANK VERSE in a POEM, or in the BIBLE, each phrase spaced apart from the next - and say to the House, as I said to those who have joined the government -
- and say to the House, as I said to those who have joined the government —
WINSTONS car is stationary in the internal courtyard at Parliament. WINSTON, in the back seat (with ELIZABETH LAY in the front, her TYPE-WRITER on her knee, typing away) dictates.  25.

- I have nothing to offer but blood, toil--tears--and sweat. EXTREME CLOSE ON: her keys typing: “sweat!” CLOSE ON: The PAGE being tugged from the TYPEWRITER. WINSTON alights the car, and ELIZABETH passes the PAGES o the SPEECH, which he grabs, then hurries away.
ANGLE ON: ERNLE HASTINGS, unable to take his eyes off CHAMBERLAIN, waiting for the HANDKERCHIEF to be waved. ANGLE ON WINSTON: readying himself for the final assault!

We have before us an ordeal of the most grievous kind. We have before us many, many long months of struggle and of suffering. You ask, what is our policy? I say it is to wage war by sea, land and air, with all our might and with all the strength God can give us--to wage war against a monstrous tyranny never surpassed in the dark and lamentable catalogue of human crime. ANGLE ON: HALIFAX, in the GALLERY - he shoots a look to CHAMBERLAIN. WINSTON (CONT’D) That is our policy. You ask, what is our aim? I can answer in one word. Victory - victory at all costs, victory in spite of terror, victory however long and hard the road may be. For without victory, there is no survival. WINSTON feels he must have won them over, but his confide smile fades as he realises he stands alone. Small KNUCKLE-KNOCKING begins - but it is MUTED. SIMON and HOARE and the other CONSERVATIVE PLOTTERS all l to CHAMBERLAIN, as he — - puts his WHITE HANDKERCHIEF back in his BREAST POCKET!! The TORIES sit back - NONE APPLAUD.  26.
CHAMBERLAIN, attempting to catch his breath, sits on a be looking across the rose in bloom so ripe they’re almost rotten. HALIFAX sees, then approaches CHAMBERLAIN.
“Our policy is to wage war--At all costs--No survival”. Winston is incapable of pronouncing the word peace, let alone engaging in peace talks. He sits next to CHAMBERLAIN.
Awful, the thought that I shall never see my country at peace again.
Neville? CHAMBERLAIN turns and faces HALIFAX - ashen faced.
I have cancer.
Oh Neville.
Winston must be removed from office.
How?
A vote of “no confidence”.

If we can get him to declare that he refuses to consider a negotiated peace with Germany then perhaps you and I will have grounds to resign. The party wont stand for that, you’re still the chairman for heavens sake, that will force a vote of “no confidence” in his leadership and he’1ll be finished.
And would you agree to be Prime Minister?  27.
With Winston out of the way ... who can say, but the important thing, Neville, is that your policies, of peace and the protection of this nation, would be back on the table.
On record.
Pardon?
He must declare on record his refusal to engage in peace talks, we must have it in writing. HALIFAX’s eyes glisten with renewed purpose.

ELIZABETH LAYTON makes her way to work, but today it’s a location - the grand TREASURY BUILDING in WHITEHALL, crossing, through traffic, Horse Guards Road and entering through the pillared main doors...

ECU - Elizabeth’s hand signs the Official Secrets Act whi is duly stamped. An elderly CIVIL SERVANT hands her a security pass. JOHN EVANS meets ELIZABETH in the lobby and leads her dow an INCONSPICUOUS DOOR where a SOLDIER checks her security pass.

EVANS leads ELIZABETH down a narrow staircase that leads the SECRET WAR-ROOMS, the underground nerve centre of BRI HIGH COMMAND. But the place is very humble, low ceiling and narrow hallways, the rooms small. No hint of luxury here. Auster Britain.
Follow me.
What goes on down here?  28.
That’s a need to know. And you don’t. JOHN EVANS keeps walking at a brisk pace through the telephonists room. ELIZABETH, clocking her surroundings, notices a door with dial lock that reads “VACANT”.
The lavatory?
For the PM’s use only. EVANS leads her down the corridor, through a narrow room bunk beds...John Evans gestures towards them.
Sleeping quarters, for when you miss the last train. They pass the MAP ROOM -
That’s the Map Room. No women allowed.
What department is this?

Indiscretion in conversation, or any other form, within or without these rooms regarding what happens here is a statutory offense and punishable by up to two years imprisonment with hard labour. Clear?
Crystal.

Good. Elizabeth follows Evans as they stop at the War Cabinet R JOHN EVANS (CONT’D) That's the War Cabinet room--never! Don’t mean to be rough on you but them’s the rules. They arrive at the TYPISTS POOL ROOM, full of NINE bust TYPISTS.  29. JOHN EVANS (CONT’D) This is the typists room, you are allowed in here.
(In Unison) Good Morning Sir. And then indicates another Room - the door is ajar, its n bigger than a shoe-box!
And here’s you. ELIZABETH enters the tiny, windowless room not much bigge than a cupboard, containing only a desk and a chair.
She arranges her effects - a BLACK PEN, a RED PEN and a H PUNCH on her desk, and then sets carefully a PHOTOGRAPH o HANDSOME SOLDIER.

The CHIEFS OF STAFF brief WINSTON: IRONSIDE for the ARMY, DOWDING (a New Zealander) for the AIR FORCE, and a NAVAL ADMIRAL (DUDLEY POUND). CHAMBERLAIN and HALIFAX are also present - as other OFFIC all crowd in and look up at - THREE LARGE OPERATIONS MAPS of EUROPE hang on three diffe walls, each full of pins and strings to show positions - for the ARMY, ONE for the NAVY, ONE for the AIR-WAR. Down the centre of the room runs a long table bearing MULTIPLE TELEPHONES of different colors which are always RINGING...and being answered by OFFICERS of the three services. The BRIEFING begins in front of - the ARMY MAP - showing (with pins and colored string) how far WESTWARD the GERMA LINE has advanced.
Belgium and Holland may fall any hour.
The French?  30.
The entire French ninth army--some two hundred thousand men--have capitulated.
All of them?!
Capitulated. Surrendered. Deserted. It was a rout. All our land forces, roughly 300,000 men, are now in full retreat.
(to DOWDING) Air-cover? For our troops?

The Luftwaffe control the skies. We simply don’t have enough planes to challenge them. In fact, I strongly recommend we stop sending our precious fighter-planes to be wasted in France--save them for our own defence. WINSTON moves to the NAVAL MAP, showing WARSHIP DEPLOYMENTS...
And our navy--sits idle, neutralized, useless.
Our fleets no sooner come within their range than we come under blistering air attack.
Their speed is devastating. WINSTON returns to the ARMY MAP -
Panzer tanks. Plunging rapidly westward, through the centre.
But they will have to pause for fuel supplies. IRONSIDE looks at GENERAL ISMAY.
Ismay?  31.
This is not the last war, Sir. Their tanks can stop for fuel at a petrol station.
Petrol station?
The road to Paris now lies open. 7 million refugees are on the move. Collectively we are looking at the collapse of Western Europe in a few days.
Should the public be told?

Not yet. First, we must rouse our old friends to an heroic resistance. France must be saved. CAMERA moves in on the MAP... Over this, we start to dissolve in - - footage of a FLAMINGO PASSENGER PLANE in flight - - as the MAP itself dissolves into - - a real rural LANDSCAPE, as seen from above...
WINSTON’s FLAMINGO PASSENGER PLANE flies over FRENCH FIEL The PLANE is soon joined by two SPITFIRE FIGHTER ESCORTS, on each wing.

We see pilots in the cockpit looks down, a drink is poure and is taken to Winston as he looks down - His face goes grey as he sees - for the first time - CIVILIAN REFUGEES, long meandering columns of desperate humanity. On BOARD with WINSTON - ISMAY, DOWDING and IRONSIDE. The SHOCK of this plays on his face. WINSTON’s POV of: the vast tragedy. Amongst straggling vagabonds and columns of refugees. Signs of the GERMAN conquest - abandoned TANKS and ARTILLERY stand in flames.  32. CLOSE ON: A YOUNG REFUGEE BOY (his POV) looks up at WINST PLANE. He holds his left hand up to his left eye to look the plane.
This can’t go on. Must not.
A LARGE DELEGATION of CIVILIANS and MILITARY await WINSTO as WINSTON alights the PLANE and approaches down a long R CARPET. PRIME MINISTER REYNAUD steps forward and shakes WINSTON’s hand.

(to REYNAUD) Brace yourselves, I am about to add to your terrible suffering-- by speaking French. They sit at a long table in the hangar. WINSTON (CONT’D) (in bad FRENCH) Bien que notre situation soit trés grave ce n'est pas la premiére fois que nous faisons face 4 une crise, ensemble. Subtitles: Although our plight is grave, this was not the first time we has been in a crisis together.
Perhaps in English, Prime Minister.
(after a moment's offence) We have--we have survived crises before, and I am confident we will survive this one. Tell me how you plan to counter-attack.
There is no plan. Silence - then...
(in FRENCH) You must counter-attack. Premier, you must! (MORE )
(in ENGLISH) You must counter-attack! Vous devez contrattaquer! Il le faut! Gentlemen--I do not believe this Panzer breakthrough is a real invasion.
Not a real invasion? Stupefied looks from the FRENCH and ISMAY alike.
(in FRENCH) Tell this to the families of the dead perhaps.
We sincerely appreciate your efforts and optimism, but--we have lost. WINSTON seems unable/unwilling to process this -

As long as--as their tanks are not supported by infantry units they are merely little flags, stuck on the map, because the tank crews are unable to support themselves. No, I refuse to see in this spectacular raid of the German tanks a real invasion. Silence to this. Is WINSTON losing his mind?
WINSTON’s FLAMINGO takes off.
REYNAUD and DALADIER, side by side in the car, watch WINSTON’s FLAMINGO climbing into the sky -
(in FRENCH, with SUBTITLES) Il Devine! Delusional! (He's delusional)
C’est Anglais (He’s English.)  34.
SIR JOHN SIMON and LORD LONDONDERRY walk and talk along t libary gallery -
He’s an actor. In love with the sound of his own voice.
Oh I love to listen to him--but we must never take his advice. Has a hundred ideas a day. Four are good, the other 96 downright dangerous.
His father was a great orator but...
Until he lost his mind to syphilis -
How nations suffer for the sins of their fathers. Across the AISLE, STANHOPE is also talking about CHURCHIL with SIR SAMUEL HOARE -
My opinion? At this critical juncture for the empire, we have a drunkard at the wheel.
Wakes with a scotch, bottle of champagne at lunch, another at dinner, brandy and port till the wee hours...I wouldn’t let him borrow my bicycle!
KINGSLEY WOOD is talking to a COLLEAGUE -
He’s a Conservative, who defects to the Liberals--lobs grenades at us for 10 years--then flops Conservative again, as it bloody suits him! Sorry, but--he stands for one thing: himself!  35.
HALIFAX is sitting with KING GEORGE VI.
We might have to replace him, Bertie.
Replace him?!
We must strive for peace--for every son and daughter of this land so that we may emerge from this crisis with something recognisable as ‘home.'
Spoken like a true Prime Minister.

YELLOW POWDERED EGGS are being MIXED with WATER, then fri then slopped onto a plate as SCRAMBLED EGGS. On a BREAKFA TRAY (once more)are set - (in rapid cuts) BACON and POWDE EGGS, SCOTCH and SODA, a GLASS of WINE...
JOHN EVANS stands outside the LOO (whose door is closed), with a note-pad and pen, ready to record WINSTON’s instructions.
Sir, you need to reply to the Lord Privy Seal.

WINSTON sits on the TOILET, reading a French newspaper wh front page shows a picture of FRENCH SOLDIER with his arm around his FRENCH SWEETHEART, holding up his fingers in a FOR-VICTORY gesture (palm-outward). The headline is “V PO LA VICTOIRE”. Winston is sitting on the toilet.
The Privy Seal?
Yes sir?  36.
(reading) “V for Victory” WINSTON closes the newspaper, stands -— WINSTON (CONT’D) Tell the Lord Privy Seal -
- tell him I’m sealed in the Privy - We hear a flush and then WINSTON appears, wearing his pin silk dressing-gown.

- and I can only deal with one shit at a time! He goes into the bedroom, followed by EVANS, where we fin ELIZABETH LAYTON, typing at the nearby desk, and -— ANTHONY EDEN, seated in a chair beside the bed, reading WINSTON’S TYPED SPEECH... WINSTON (CONT’D) Don’t spare me, Anthony--be frank.
Mmmmm. As EDEN reads, WINSTON stares at him, awaiting his reacti

(to EDEN) I think it’s rather good. The ending especially. When EDEN says nothing the wait becomes agonizing. EDEN finishes reading the speech, turns over the last page to if there is more on the back. There isn’t. WINSTON waits for the verdict. EDEN takes off his glasses slowly and looks up at a hopeful WINSTON -
I don’t think so.
You don’t think so, what?  37.
You’re suggesting we’re--somehow-- winning. (beat) We're not.
No but...it will inspire them.
You don’t understand - Winston, I know -
(stubbornly) - no, no, no. I am going to imbue them, Anthony, with a spirit of feeling they don’t yet know they have! Silence. Stalemate. EDEN looks gravely concerned.
You asked my opinion. I caution against it. WINSTON stares at his trusted ally, his hopes fading, unt he snaps his finger, pointing at EDEN -
Cicero! He’s on the move again - heading out of the bedroom, with EVANS and LAYTON, and finally EDEN, forced to follow...
“Live as", “Live as brave men" — da,da,da - “and if fortune is adverse, something, something, something He then enters the -
(shouting)
As he looks for his book in the library he finds CLEMMIE...STRESSED, struggling to cope, busily writing CHEQUES.  38. WINSTON (CONT’D) Cat--my copy of Cicero. Did you shelve it?
Did you hear what I said?!
What’s that?
We're broke.
Everybody out! Get out! He shooes JOHN EVANS, ELIZABETH and EDEN from the room as they were cats.
I dare not write another cheque.
I’‘1l economise - only four cigars a day!
You're insufferable! (beat) Was there something else? Anything?
Yes, my love for you.
How much have you had to drink this morning? He goes to her, drawing up a chair, close -
I see you now as I first saw you in nineteen hundred and four across a crowded dance-floor. I simply stood- -speechless.
I must have been very beautiful to have achieved that miraculous effect.
Four years till we saw each other again.
They went by in an absolute flash.  39.
You didn’t lack for admirers. Your fidéle serviteur in Sidney Peel.
Brilliant man.
Lionel Earle.
Wonderful dancer.
And then--at Lady St Hellier’s dinner party--who should show up?
Pig. (little snort)
The same. They look at each other, their faces very close.
Are we terribly old?
Yes. I’m afraid you are. She LAUGHS and pushes him away. Winston takes her hand. WINSTON (CONT’D) Will you hear me read my speech for tonight's broadcast?
WINSTON emerges and is accosted by... the PRESS.

Prime Minister - the situation in France - Is it true we’re in full retreat? Is France lost? He fires the REPORTER a steely look of rebuke and then sp faces their CAMERAS, takes his CIGAR out of his mouth wit INDEX and SECOND finger and makes, for the CAMERAS, his f ever V-FOR-VICTORY SIGN (but PALM-INWARD, the RUDE VERSIO WINSTON crosses the road, practising a tongue-twister as enters the TREASURY.  40. INT. WINSTON’S OFFICE/ WAR ROOMS - NIGHT WINSTON sitting on his bed, is AGITATED, UNEASY, UNSURE n about the speech he is to deliver on RADIO. ELIZABETH LAYTON sits at a desk in the corner holding fil and paperwork. Two MICROPHONES sit on a table. An ACTOR also stands by. Producer guides Winston to his desk.
So--if you will sit here - at your desk
Mmmmm. WINSTON sits, studying with CONCERN the SPEECH lying on t table in front of him, and taking out his PEN.

- and speak slowly and clearly. Into the microphone. WINSTON starts to jot last-minute CHANGES to the SPEECH. Increasingly PRESSURISED, he CROSSES OUT the CHANGES he j made, and tries to write alternatives. He’s clearly ina state. BBC PRODUCER (CONT’D) So--if you are ready--on the stroke of 9 the light will go red, and we shall go live to the nation. Nine O Clock. Red light. You begin. Yes? But WINSTON isn’t ready. He’s too busy trying to rewrite speech The SWEEP SECOND HAND on the WALL CLOCK approaches 12. The PRODUCER, and ELIZABETH, become very concerned now as last seconds vanish - BBC PRODUCER (CONT’D) Prime Minister? Are we ready?
(to himself) One moment, one moment —
We are going live. Prime -—
(exploding)
This eruption stuns the PRODUCER and ELIZABETH. WINSTON’s hand, holding the PEN, shakes now with indecisi as he fails to think of the right words in time -

Four--three--two--one... On the stroke of 9 pm, the light goes RED, bathing him in light. They are LIVE. SILENCE. TOTAL SILENCE. The PRODUCER is now in a panic. WINSTON seems frozen for a second, until - WINSTON takes a breath and begins...

“I speak to you for the first time as Prime Minister in a solemn hour for the life of our country, of our Empire, of our allies, and, above all, of the cause of Freedom. A tremendous battle is raging in France and Flanders.” ELIZABETH sighs relief, then follows on her carbon copy, mouthing the words, many of which she knows by heart. CAMERA follows the WIRES that lead out of the office, dow the corridor, and into the TRANSMITTER ROOM. Reveal BBC R Recorder men.
PULL BACK to reveal: The KING, looking up from the PAPER, he listens to WINSTON’s speech on the radio, and studies FRAMED FAMILY PHOTOS of his CHILDREN...Princesses ELIZABE and MARGARET.

“The Germans...by a remarkable combination of air bombing and heavily armored tanks, have broken through the French defenses north of the Maginot Line, and strong columns of their armoured vehicles are ravaging the open country...” CLOSE ON: NEWSPAPER - the HEADLINE reads: IN CONTROL, SAY FRENCH Despite Nazi Raid  42.
HALIFAX sits at the table, a minister standing behind him they listen to Winston’s radio address

“,..which for the first day or two was without defenders...But!...I have invincible confidence in the French Army and its leaders. Only a very small part of that splendid Army has yet been heavily engaged; and only a very small part of France has yet been invaded...Side by side, the British and French peoples--have advanced...” HALIFAX is disgusted by this DISTORTION of the facts.
“Advanced”?! How bloody dare he!
AERIAL SHOT OF: the BRITISH and FRENCH armies in retreat leaving behind SMOKING TRUCKS and ABANDONED ARTILLERY. TRACKING OVER this ravaged landscape, we see-
- the abstracted landscape of a human CORPSE...

“,..the British and French peoples-—- have advanced--to rescue not only Europe, but mankind from the foulest and most soul-destroying tyranny which has ever darkened and stained the pages of history. .-.-until an EYE is revealed in CLOSE-UP, staring into CA INT. WINSTON’S OFFICE/ WAR ROOMS - NIGHT CLOSE-UP ON: the RED RECORDING LIGHT.

“But now one bond unites us all - to wage war until victory is won, and never to surrender ourselves to servitude and shame, whatever the cost and the agony may be...Conquer we must, as conquer we shall.” CLOSE-UP ON: WINSTON’s FACE...  43.
Well done, sir. WINSTON sits back - UNHAPPY. CLOSE-UP ON: the RED RECORDING LIGHT goes off. The BROADC is over.
CLEMMIE turns off the RADIO, concerned.
WINSTON, UNHAPPY, walks up to a DOOR, enters it -
- then walks down the long tunnel (connecting the WAR ROO with DOWNING STREET) until, at its end, he enters an ELEV
- WINSTON rides the ELEVATOR upward -
- WINSTON exits the ELEVATOR, and begins to climb the sta
You did marvelously.
For the last ten years I was the only one who told them the truth. Until tonight. There’s no advance. It’s a shambles. We’re in full retreat.
Would you be serving them tonight by denying them sleep, terrifying their children?
Even if the terror is coming?!
Because it’s coming! There is time enough for truth.
He nods, accepting this. He walks off, still anxious. She watches him go, worried.

The front page of a newspaper: a PHOTO of WINSTON doing h FOR VICTORY SIGN (palm inward). ELIZABETH LAYTON, leaning by the door, reading the paper. At her side stands another typist, SYBIL, reading another copy of the same PAPER -— ELIZABETH is giggling - WINSTON passes the doorway in the corridor, then re-appea
What’s so funny?
Prime Minister sir -
Go on. What is it?
ELIZABETH steps out into the corridor so they can have so privacy -
Not sure if you know this but-- the way you are doing your V For Victory sign--well, in the poorer quarters that gesture means--something else.
What does it mean?
Wouldn’t like to say sir.
I was captured by the Boer. I spent time in a South African prison.
Up yer’ bum. Sir.
Up yer’ bum? WINSTON roars with LAUGHTER - which sets ELIZABETH laughi  45.
The way you do it, sir. Yes sir. (demonstrates) But if you turn it around - (palm out) - that’s fine.
I see.
Wouldn’t like millions of people to take it the wrong way. WINSTON steps away, still chuckling -
Up yer’ bum! INT. BUCKINGHAM PALACE / WINSTON’S OFFICE, WAR ROOMS - DA KING GEORGE speaks into the TELEPHONE -
Don’t wish to take too much of your time. (pause) I heard you--on the--wireless.
Was I comprehensible?
The public need to be led, not misled--not left to work it out for them-themselves.
Right. Will that be all, your majesty?
Yes. Good day Prime Minister. (click) WINSTON puts down the PHONE and turns to EVANS.
I believe I’ve just recieved a royal rap on the knuckles.
PRESENT: 17 PERSONS. The Main War Cabinet, minus WINSTON (CHAMBERLAIN, HALIFAX, GREENWOOD, ATLEE) and the FOLLOWIN

head_text.subj: DOWDING, IRONSIDE, BRIDGES, ISMAY, NICHOLL, WILKINSON

text: CABINET SECRETARY BRIDGES is helping to seat everyone as move around the table looking for their placement card.

(indicating to HALIFAX's seat) Foreign Minister? A NEW MAP shows the NEW POSITIONS of BRITISH TROOPS. SURR at DUNKIRK. Finally, WINSTON enters, shakes the hands of IRONSIDE and first, but has less enthusiasm for ATTLEE and GREENWOOD, nothing for CHAMBERLAIN and HALIFAX, who do not expect to their hands shaken.

Tiny, good to see you. (to ISMAY) Pug. Welcome to the War Cabinet, such as we are. (to ALL) Please, sit. He sits. WINSTON (CONT’D) War is usually a catalogue of blunders, and this one is proving no exception. (beat) General - its all yours.
You have this morning’s report in front of you -
Yes. General -

- if you turn to page 3 - Ummm - so on page 3 - are we all Looking at page 3? - no, the other document - second paragraph down - WINSTON, agitated, reeling from the royal reprimand, taps wedding ring finger on the side of his chair impatiently
Second?  47.
Yes, the second--no, page - WINSTON can stand it no longer - Silence -
(his patience snapping) Edmund!--why don’t you just tell us- -please--in your own words-- what kind of mess we are looking at here. What’s going on?

Right. (beat) As of 2200 hours last night--the Germans have encircled sixty British, Belgian and French divisions. On our part all our forces under Lord Gort have now withdrawn, or are trying to withdraw, to the French coast, to Dunkirk, where we cannot reach them. Ships sunk by the Nazis block the harbour entrance and the Luftwaffe control the skies above.
How many of our men are trapped?
All of them. (pause) Our nation’s entire professional soldiery. And... (pause) .-..we can see no clear way to rescue them.
General--are you telling me that we shall have lost the British army by the next few days?
That’s correct.
What are the French doing?
Premiere Raynaud sent a radio message. He expects the defence of Paris will soon fail.  48.
We must counter-attack. Anyone? (silence) Surely -
The German forces are superior in every regard and are only fifty miles from the coast. They are pushing us into the sea.
Fifty miles! Good God!
For a German tank, two days.
They must not reach the sea! Not before we evacuate our men! General Ismay? What have you got for us?
Everyone looks at ISMAY.
As it stands--I cannot see that we have much hope of getting any of our forces out in time. A gasp in the cabinet. WINSTON takes this news badly.

Not a man? We cannot be so totally at their mercy! REACTION HALIFAX: Only just holding his tongue. He looks CHAMBERLAIN, who does not maintain the look. WINSTON (CONT’D) General. What is our next step?
I’m not sure, sir, that we have one. Silence. A pall settles. ISMAY looks at IRONSIDE, who say nothing. CHAMBERLAIN and HALIFAX also exchange a look.
So? So where are we to look for salvation? (silence) Anyone? Come on! Speak!
We still have a Garrison at Calais. 25 miles to the west.
Well why didn’t you say so?! How Many men do we have there?
4,000. More or less.

Then have them go east--engage with the German columns moving on Dunkirk. Buy us some time. Draw the Nazi focus away from Dunkirk whilst we execute a maritime evacuation of our forces. Ironside--is that possible?
It would mean a huge sacrifice.
Four thousand young men!
To save 300,000! (pause) Under whose command is the Calais Garrison?
Brigadier Nicholson. Silence. The burden falls on Winston...

Very well--tell... A hint of UNCERTAINTY here, as WINSTON taps his SIGNET RI on the wooden arm of his chair. WINSTON (CONT’D) ...tell--Nicholson--that it is of the greatest importance to this island that his garrison draw the enemy’s tanks and artillery and bombers away from Dunkirk--invite their wrath--and to--to fight on if needs be until--until the destruction of his command. A PALL settles over the room. Almost a GASP.
It’s suicide. HALIFAX, emotions rising, can stay silent no longer.  50.
Prime Minister! I have reservations...
Who is free of reservations?
-..-about such a fateful course when we have the option of a peace offer.
What peace offer?!
The Italians have offered to mediate between ourselves and Germany. And I indicated that provided our liberty and independence were assured, we would consider any proposal.
With Hitler holding the whip hand do you really think he would honour our liberty and independence?
It would be in his interest to do so. He -

The only thing to do is to show that maniac that he cannot conquer this country, and for that we need an army. General, tell Brigadier Nicholson, “The Germans must not reach the sea! Not before we get our boys off that bloody beach!" (pause) I take full responsibility.
Really?
(temper exploding) REALLY! YES! It is the reason I sit in this chair!
Surely--before we send 4,000 men to their graves, we must explore -
(frustrated) What is this?!  51.

What is your mind on the principle of peace talks? Do we take it for example, that you preclude yourself from even considering engaging in such negotiations? A TENSE SILENCE. ANGLE ON: the TWO SECRETARIES, pencil’s raised, waiting t record WINSTON’s reply. WINSTON, aware that history is listening, senses a TRAP -

I should like to speak to Viscount Halifax and Mr Chamberlain alone. (to IRONSIDE) Issue the order to the Calais Garrison. Confirm it has been done. (to BRIDGES) Bridges! You too! Out! Hop it! BRIDGES puts down his pencil. Consternation from those departing at this breach of protocol.
At the end of the line of unneeded WAR CABINET members fi out, comes the disgruntled BRIDGES with his TWO SECRETARI
WINSTON lights his CIGAR, and takes his time, slowly appr the HALIFAX seated at the back of the room.
Winston. We are facing certain defeat on land--the annihilation of our army--and imminent invasion! We must be rational!

We are a sea-going nation. Have been since the Bronze Age. The Channel is ours--our moat--our battlement and the German doesn’t recognise an expanse of water greater than a bloody lake! They have first to reach this island -  52.
- which will be full of terrified men, women and children, whom we have failed, despicably, in our duty of protection. Germany has won- -we are entirely defenceless -
And who's fault is that ?! CHAMBERLAIN averts his face.

- facing the largest army the world has seen. Furthermore, once France falls, Germany can concentrate on aircraft production and they will then have the French fleet as well! What is to stop Hitler then? Words? Words, Winston? Words alone? (beat) If you will not permit any talk of peace then I will be forced - CHAMBERLAIN steps in, to stop Halifax from resigning.

Might we not allow Edward simply to meet the Italian ambassador, Bastianini--discuss their possible role as mediators between us and Germany, and find out their price? WINSTON is calmed by CHAMBERLAIN’s manner -
Bastianini? Ha! A man about whom we might say there is less to him than meets the eye. WINSTON looks at HALIFAX, and sighs - WINSTON (CONT’D) I remain opposed to any negotiations -
- of course -
- which might lead to a derogation of our rights and power.
AS DO WE ALL! There is no question that our sovereignty is non- negotiable!  53.
Winston? With nowhere left to turn - WINSTON gives a slow inclinat of the head, and then - NODS. CHAMBERLAIN (CONT’D) Good. Thank you.
-.-but! No-one outside this room must ever know.
Of course.
WINSTON walks through the corridors - then approaches and opens a SMALL LAVATORY DOOR. As he enters - CLOSE ON: The door’s lock, which slides from “VACANT” to “ENGAGED”.

Inside, it’s no LAVATORY. It is actually - a secret PRIVA TELEPHONE SYSTEM, linking WINSTON with the ROOSEVELT WHIT HOUSE. WINSTON, seated, holding the receiver, takes a few moment before he lifts the phone to his ear -—
Mr President?
Winston!
How are you Franklin?
Fine. Fine. How are you Prime Minister?
I am phoning about--about your Navy ships. If you were to loan us just 50 of your older Destroyers I feel sure —
Ah! Yes!  54.
- even 40 would - Well I - ROOSEVELT (CONT’D) - I did ask around, but just not possible I’m afraid. The Neutrality Act we signed last year has tied my hands. Just can’t swing it. I tried.
Then--can I--do I have your permission to send an aircraft carrier to pick up the P-40 fighter planes we purchased? Mr President.
(wincing, hating not being able to help) You got me there again. New law-- preventing trans-shipment of military equipment.
But we’ve paid for them--with the money we borrowed from you!
(anguished) So sorry, Winston.
I need not impress upon you the trouble faced by the Western Hemisphere. Without your support, in some fashion... Silence. A tense moment...
I know. I know. You are on my mind day and night. (pause) Look. We could--possibly... But words fail the hampered ROOSEVELT and his voice trail off.
Mr President--we are facing the gravest odds!  55.

.-.-we could take your planes to about a mile from the Canadian border--and then if you send across a team of horses from Canada-- nothing motorized--then you could pull ‘em over the border yourself. How does that sound?
Horses? You said “a team of horses"?
I guess you could push ‘em yourself. The damn things have wheels. Up to you. WINSTON is speechless - ROOSEVELT (CONT’D) We could do that. (silence) Prime Minister?
WINSTON covers the PHONE, bunches his fist, swallows his RAGE, and then speaks again, as calmly as he can-
Anything you can do at this time would be welcome.
Goodnight to you Winston. (feeling WINSTON's pain) It must be late there?
In more ways than you could possibly know. He puts down the phone and sits back in his chair - stunn fuming. But as he stews, he slowly - slowly - conceives a idea, a new IDEA!

WINSTON enters and strides past the staff, making for the LARGE MAP of EUROPE. He puts his finger on the FRENCH COA at DUNKIRK, encircled by RED THREAD. And then looks at ENGLAND, the COAST, and then taps DOVER on the map. He turns, sees the DOZEN colorful TELEPHONES and addresse
Get me Vice-Admiral Ramsay on one of these.
HIGH AERIAL of the CASTLE atop the famous WHITE-CLIFFS.
